section.name: Conventions used by EasyConf
section.p: EasyConf follows a set of conventions to make it easier to use. Here is a list or the conventions currently in use:

ul.li: Given a component named my-component its base configuration properties will be obtained from a file named my-component.properties and its XML file will be obtained from a file named my-component.xml
For every component a file named global-configuration.properties will be read to find overridden property values.

The property names of the global-configuration.properties file may be prefixed by the name of the component followed by a colon character. For example:
my-component:property-name=property-value

A special property named include-and-override can be used to include files. In case of collision of property names the included ones will override the values given in the file which contains the inclusion instruction. If several include-and-override files are used, the last ones will override any previous property values

Filters are formed by a set of property selectors. When converted to a string the selectors are separated by a semi-colon and the set is separated from the property value with a colon. Example:
property-name:selector1.selector2=property-value

section.p: Other significant strategies of EasyConf are:

ul.li: Any file looked for that doesn't exist will be silently ignored. An exception is if the properties of a component is explicitly requested and there is no properties file or the object configuration is explicitly requested and there is no XML file
